38869422.review:
For $80.00, no.

Honestly, I have to put that out there ahead of anything else I'm about to write. The standard price for this is absurdly high, especially given that this came out some time ago, now.

But for $25.00 during a sale, sure. It has its flaws, and among them is that some pretty important battles (Bagration) are somehow in the DLC rather than the base game, and some battles (Citadel, AKA Kursk) don't even appear to be available at all. Also, it's sometimes needlessly complex (once I group together units, do I really need to Shift-Right Click to attack with the group? Just a right click should do if I bothered to group them, after all) while in other areas somehow still watered-down (partisans are a whack-a-mole annoyance rather than a crucial issue, much of the time).

All that said, have you ever played Unity of Command and wanted a bigger scenario with more complexity? Well, this is basically just that: the biggest UoC scenario is about the scale in space of the medium-sized ones in WitE, and about half the scale in turns.

If you don't know what Unity of Command is, here's another take:

Ever played Civilization games and wanted to do nothing but fight battles with the end-game units? This is basically that, sans helicopters and giant death robots. You'll spend countless turns shuffling across hexes, defending hexes, stacking units (up to three in a tile) according to what you plan on happening, and, of course, fighting for cities (as well as victory points). There's a lot more military complexity, too, and none of that stupidly-simple diplomacy that Civilization fans have come to know and occasionally tolerate.

And beyond all that: if you are a war-gamer, this is one of the most detailed titles in PC war-gaming that you'll find.


But it has its flaws. 

I already mentioned the pricing, but the price might feel a little less astronomical if certain other flaws didn't also exist. 

For one, the music: you get maybe a grand total of 7 minutes of actual music, divided into 2 tracks. And one of the two tracks, while an excellent attempt at a very martial-sounding march, is itself already repetative. While I don't want to compare HoI4 to this, as the two games are actually quite different in many ways, I have to say that HoI4 itself annoyed me musically, as it had maybe 20 minutes of music at launch and you heard the same stuff over and over again over a 5-10 hour campaign. But WitE is far worse... in just the first hour of actual play, I already found myself thinking about putting on my own music. 

Another pretty major non-gameplay-related flaw is the lack of useful tool-tips. You get tool-tips, yes, but most are not very useful and are often limited to a single-sentence that doesn't connect the question at hand to the other gameplay elements. This is an issue in other games, sure, but in a game with such a massive amount of text, how is it that tool-tips are so small? This game doesn't hold hands, but maybe some better tool-tips, at least, would be a good idea... especially given that the manual also doesn't always provide a straight-forward answer (or always explain what an acronym means, or what a couple of gameplay mechanics actually do).

Yet another lack-of-polish issue is that the DLC campaign scenarios are intermingled with the base-game scenarios in the menu. This sounds nit-picky, but when you just want to try the base-game prior to deciding on DLC, it only serves to obscure what you really can play. Worse, the tutorial scenario, because it begins with a 'V' for its name (named after the area it occurs in), is buried in the list... fortunately, V is close enough to T (for Tutorial, you know) that I still found it while looking for a tutorial scenario... but really? You know, seperate folders for game content have been around since Doom had the different WAD files for maps. Doom, guys. Doom. A game that was little more than blasting demons had the foresight to use different folders for maps. And here we are twenty years later with a major war-game that lumps every map into the same folder.

And still another non-gameplay-issue: resolution and full-screen. Resolution can be screwy, and I toyed around with mine a little bit (though fortunately I didn't run into any black-screen issues or more major stuff like some on the Steam forums may have). And true full-screen doesn't exist... a major war-game without even the option to go full-screen. Again, Doom, guys. Doom.


So why still recommend it?

Well, if you don't mind getting through a couple of beginner's traps, don't mind a sort of high learning curve, and don't mind putting on some Moody Blues, then you can jump into a far better depiction of the Eastern Front than you saw in CoH2, HoI4, or in almost any other strategy game. 

This is as close as you can get to seeing what really was going on in the Eastern Front. If you allow the Soviets to pull back in those early-war scenarios, you may not get another chance to encircle them. The Panzers often must move forward, keeping the Soviets routing, not allowing them to entrench at the rivers, all while realizing that fuel may become an issue and that once the mud appears, that's it. Unlike most games that depict the winter weather being the downfall of the offensive in 1941, this one accurately shows that the *mud* actually was the beginning of the end, as the Panzers couldn't get ahead fast enough at that point to keep the Soviets retreating.

Really, it's those things that make this game what it is. It's the over-all attention to the military realities, acknowledging that ammunition and fuel are two totally seperate things (unlike HoI4 or UoC), acknowledging that you can't simply empty France and Germany to deploy every last unit against the Soviets (an issue many, many WWII games have run into, where you can win on the Eastern Front by taking everyone who should have had to stay in France and using them in the East, all because the human player knows that the scripted invasion of France won't hit until 1944). Not that the Western Front exists in WitE, but enough scenarios force one or both players to leave garrisons in certain cities in the Eastern Theater in order to not lose victory points.


TL;DR - 

Very good gameplay, very thread-bare presentation (music is ultra-repetative, some UI elements are poor). 

For $25 (and $10 on I-tunes for some better music), it's worth it. Maybe for $40 if you are really into hex-based wargaming. 

But for $80, I'd say wait for a sale. 

Definitely a game I recommend, but, well, not for $80.00. Hopefully they chop the standard price in half (at least) before long, but that hardly seems likely from what I've seen... and to anyone still trying to defend the current price: the game is way too old now to justify the price. Super Mario Bro's for the NES in the 1980's might be an all-time classic... but they don't still charge the $30 original price (or whatever it was, adjusting for inflation, etc.). In all likelihood, if the price was set to $25.00 (which it is during winter sales), it would probably make *more* money that way, selling two dozen more copies a year, than it does currently probably selling a couple copies a year at $80.00.

37449040.review:
HOI 4 vs War in the East:

HOI 4:
Abstracted number of men in your army with a limited OOB.
Limited number of Generals.
Weird Supply system.

War in the East:
Precise number of men in an amazing OOB.
Every single General that fought on the Eastern Front including the Axis Minors and they can be dimissed or shot for bad performance.
Complex and a more realistic supply system. You even need to change the Russian rail gauge to German standards to keep supplies flowing! (Not as good as War in the West tho).

HOI 4 does however focus on the whole war and has naval combat. However, the level of detail is amazing in War in the East and if you like detail you will love this game!

36881324.review:
Immense and dense.  After grappling with basic mechanics and how the game plays.  You'll play a few turns and discover that Logistics and Army management is another whole meta game.  Once you get something of a handle on Logistics you'll be off and running...NO you won't.  Because all of sudden you have to get to grasps with weather effects screwing up your movement with mud and snow and then your rail links are getting broken up faster than you can repair them and partisans have sprung up across your entire rear.

The game is a masterpiece, a monster, a leviathan that needs to be wrestled with mentally.  Do not play if you want a cut and paste simplistic game like Total War.  GGWITE will sit there waiting to mug your lobes and make you suffer in analysis paralysis.  Computer games are really the best thing to happen to "Monster Wargames" transitiong from cardboard to silicon really allows the games design to shine.

The game is contiuing to be updated, mods are available for it on the Matrix forums, and the rumor is that GGWITE along with GGWITW are going to be combined for a truly epic 2 front monster in the future.  Squee.  Can't wait for that monster to punish me :)

Komplexná wargame. Momentálne odohraných 30 ťahov za 16 hodín. 
Pred kúpou je potrebné počítať s tým že je manuál anglický. 
Tiež pred kúpou odporúčam prezrieť videá ktoré mi pomohly sa zorientovať. 
Manuál som musel prekladať cez translator, ale za pár hodín sa človek do toho dostane. 
Pre efektívnosť ťahu som si ťah rozdelil na 12 fáz, aby som na nič nezabudol.

1. presun Fabrík pri hrozbe obsadenia
2. presun utekajúcich jednotiek do bezpečia
3. letecký prieskum, kontrola počasia
4. zmena velenia na poste veliteľa
5. stavba opevnenia 
6. letecké zásobovanie
7. oprava železníc
8. pohyb jednotiek
9. bombardovanie letísk
10.pohyb nových jednotiek
11. útoky
12. vytvorenie ´podporných jednotiek a vytvorenie bojových jednotiek

To je pre stručný prehľad s čím sa treba zaoberať. 
Je vhodné si rozdeliť fázy. Môže sa stať že presuniete nové jednotky po železniciach 
a napokom zistíte že vám neostanú body pre presun na železnici pre ohrozenú továreň (fabriku)
Je toho ešte dosť čo by trebalo vedieť. Zatiaľ som to skúšal na easy obtiažnosti za sovietov. 
Je to drsné vytvárať obranné línie a oslobodzovať jednotky z obkľúčení. 

Pred kúpou som pokukoval po stolných doskovkách od GMT, ale myslím tento kúsok mi to 
celkom nahradí. Hru som zakúpil v akcii za 55 € a môžem ju odporučiť. 
Zvažoval som že v budúcnosti by som spravil tutorial videá keďže nič také neni v slovenskom či českom jazyku.
Ale jedná sa o úvahu. Pôvodne ma odradzoval 350 stranový manuál v angličtine. 

Ak by niekto nový potreboval poradiť s hrou, môžem pomôcť. 
Upozorňujem,  najlepšie je si pozrieť videá aby človek vedel do čoho sa púšťa.
Táto hra veru neni pre každého.

čiže hodnotenie

35470161.review:
Imaginez le plaisir de trouver enfin un wargame traditionnel sur PC : hexagones, ZOC, ravitaillement et ordres de bataille d’une précision incroyable. La carte est superbe, les scenarii variés. Et plusieurs campagnes ! Le passionné du front de l’est pense y trouver enfin le graal. Et pourtant…
L’interface est digne des jeux MS-DOS –les concepteurs auraient pu s’inspirer de Heart of Iron qui trace des lignes pour montrer l’attachement des unités aux différentes armées ; le bouton droit de la souris ne sert qu’à effectuer un type d’attaque. Navrant et pénible. Exemple particulièrement lourdingue : pour changer la couleur d’un HQ afin de faciliter la lecture de la carte, il faut rentrer les valeurs RGB (oui, oui !!!....).
Sur la forme, c’est donc calamiteux.
Sur le fond ? On se trouve en permanence face à des situations ubuesques avec des unités parfois isolées géographiquement mais qui reçoivent quand même du ravitaillement ; des lignes qui passent à travers les ZOC adverses, des reculs d’unités dans des directions bizarres. Il n’y a aucune différence entre la gestion du ravitaillement du côté allemand ou soviétique.
On passe un temps insensé à faire du micro-management avec chasseurs et bombardiers, alors que l’aviation a joué un rôle mineur à l’est contrairement à l’ouest. La quantité d’avions gêne parfois la lisibilité de la carte.
Les concepteurs ont pensé qu’il suffisait de balancer un superbe ordre de bataille pour faire un wargame ; ils ont malheureusement ignoré les tactiques allemandes et russes, fondamentalement différentes. Superbe gâchis.

Tahle hra, to je strategický hardcore. Hrajete na tahy, kdy jeden tah = jeden týden války na východě. Můžete hrát obří kampaň, která má přes 250 tahů, začít Barbarosou a skončit obsazením Berlína, nebo si můžete dát jen kratší kampaň, třeba na dobytí Leningadu (17 tahů). Ovládáte kupu jednotek, máte možnost jednotky tvořit, rozpuštět, míchat, doplňovat podpůrnýma zbraněma a mnoho mnoh dalšího. Sám nevím, kolik toho vlastně můžu v téhle hře udělat.

34333962.review:
The game would be great if it would let you actually play.

Many say that this game is too complicated. It is not. It is just deep. True, learning the game is a pain. Period. But it does not take that much time to get into it, 3-4 hours and you should be good with most mechanics. 

So, is it fun? Yes. It is a challenge and the way the mechanics work, the results of actions make sense. E.g. what you expect to happen in certain situations, like storming a city or attacking across a river or encircling an enemy unit, will give you the results you expect. It is a good "military" simulator rather than a tic-tac-toe puzzle system a la panzer general. 

HOWEVER:
The larger the game gets (the bigger the scenario and the further in you get), the longer the time the computer takes to calculate its turn. This is because the AI calculates what it wants to do. In the small scenarios, this is basically irrelevant. But I have been playing the big campaign on the soviet side and am now on turn 58.

It takes the computer 45 minutes to calculate its turn!!!! I'm sorry, but what?! 

I would really have liked to finish the campaign (standing at mid-1942 at this point) but I am not going to wait for 45 mins for one turn (= 1 in-game week) to pass. This is even more frustrating as, as a Soviet, I'm not doing much in my own turn at this time in the war. So I'm busy for 3-5 minutes and then wait for almost an hour.

If you really want to play the Great Patriotic War, I would suggest War In The East 1. It's an old DOS game that will give you eye cancer and has very odd controls but once you get used to it, it will at least let you finish the game.

Edit: To address arguments that my computer is just too old: I have an i7-5500 CPU with 2,4 GHz and 12GB RAM. If that is not good enough for a hex-based counter game that is on the technological level of 1998, I'd be surprised.

33731087.review:
This is a good game, I suppose. The times I take the time to actually play it I do find it enjoyable, and it's challenging in a fun way to try to do better each time I play the incrementally larger scenarios, and the depth, while I feel it's ridiculously overdone, can be cool, too. You don't have to tinker with which divisions get the best commanders or priority for that howitzer battalion, which I really appreciate, but you can spend time on this to give yourself an extra edge should you want to.

It's just a pity the game is so ridiculously micro-intensive. Building rails consists of moving rail units one hex, giving it the relevant order, moving it the next hex, and so on. Every single turn. You can't tell a unit to move to a distant hex over several turns. You can't select units in several hexes and tell them to move towards a single hex, you have to select them one by one.

Someone please correct me if I'm wrong on any of these, but I really wish quality of life improvements were prioritised in future patches.

Summary: [i]If you're not used to complex strategy games, pass this one by. My "record" is Hearts of Iron 3, and even then I find this a bit too daunting at times.[/i]

This game is currently the ultimate computer game available on the topic of the 1941-45 War In The East between Germany and Russia.  It is a typical "Grognard" game in the style of Gary Grigsby's previous War In The Pacific:AE game.  If you liked that, you will like this more since it is more manageable.  This game has received continuing patch support since it was published. I have been playing it since 2013 and can attest to the fact that it has been truly polished and improved over time and is stable, reasonably balanced, loaded with optional "tweaking" adjustments you can tune to taste, and well worth the time that is involved in playing a monster of this depth (which reaches down to the brigade level !)

If you are interested in WW2 history of the "War In The East", you can't go wrong with this game.

32894483.review:
This is a review after reading half of 380+ pages manual and playing a couple of small scenarios. So this is stilll a review based on first impressions, rather full insight into details ;) 

But wow - this game is complex in the best meaning of the word. If you like complexity - that is the game for you. If you like board games - that is the game for you. If you are not afraid of some micromanagement - that is the game for you. If you like Aurora (best 4x game ever) - WitE is a game for you! You need to invest some time to understand the game... But unlike with many other games - the more you get to know, the more it is clear to you that the game is really well done. 
To be honest - I must point out that there are downsides:
- price - 70 EUR is a joke - I bought at summer sale for 30+ - still too much, but I could not resist the temptation :)
- "moderate" user friendlines - interface and some aspects of map display (e.g. OOB) could easily be better;
- learnign curve - it is steep :)  - full campaigns seem overwhelming due to sheer number of units and issues (logistics!);
- "racing" scenarios -  by nature I am a bit slow and cautious, therefore I do not like some of the short offensive scenarios which tend to become a race to the target - it is not at all that primitive as in Panzer Commander and Panzer Corps series, but still it is not to my liking!

32774575.review:
Fantastic game for those who have time and patient to learn it. 

If you want a strategy game that covers an entire front during WW2; this is the game!
The number of units and the size of the map can be daunting for a new player. BUT as an experienced strategy gamer I did not find GG War in the East harder to learn than for example Hearts of Iron 2/3/4. This is a combat focused game on a strategic level. The production and economy in the game is much simplified. The AI is better than i most other turn based games (looking at you civilization and Total War). 

The majority of the game time goes to moving your hundreds of units around. Expect 100+ hours for a full campaign. So the biggest downside with this game is that it takes considerable time. On the other hand my favourite game The Witcher 3 also took me 100+ hours. 

The price is high compared to other games and this is not even a new game. So grab it on a sale and I strongly recommend buying the expansions for some really good designed, new player friendly scenarios.

29818591.review:
My Goodness this is a complex, complex game. If you are interested in military history and want to know what really happened on the Russian front in World War Two, then buy this game.

And then weep as your puny human brain is unable to comprehend the sheer complexity of reality as it is brilliantly simulated in praiseworthy detail by the genius who made this game. Cry as you realise you don't know the first thing about operational art, organising corps, armies or army groups, and that far from being like Gary Kasparov and thinking 50 moves ahead, you can barely comprehend the next turn or two.

Fear the Russian Winter. Fear the Russian reserves. Fear the total strategic paralysis of invading Russia and realising you bit off waaaay more than you can chew.

Then be thankful you live in an age where a game like this is available. Truly, if there is a more complex, realistic and delightfully frightful simulation of one of the most awful conflicts in human history, I have never seen it. The detail is staggering, it will push you to a whole new level. 

An expensive game, but worth every penny because there is nothing even close.

29385551.review:
I really wanted to give this game a positive rating, but I cannot.

I write this for potential buyers, who, like me are taken aback by the very steep price.

I watched this game for over a year, and in most sales it is 50% off, but never cheaper. And since it is an old game it will probably stay that way.

This is a very serious WW2 simulator, and in the hex based/counter genre the most encompassing game I have played. All units and leaders are historically accurate (as far as I can tell, and I know a thing or two about WW2), and units come with very detailed information and historical photographs. 

It is not a dynamic, or graphically appealing game, all fighting is autoresolved, so it is mostly a game of strategic planning, concentrating your troops and building up fronts. 

The AI is pretty decent, for example: It detects attempts to encircle and tries to avoid that. But since the German units start off way better (really rather overpowered, as their historical edge lay at least half in communication, coordination, speed and organisation, things that cannot easily be programmed, so to simulate the advantage of the Germans, their troops are very strong compared to Soviet troops), and since the unit values favors defense greatly for both sides, the Soviet Ai hardly ever attacks and is overall rather passive. Basically the AI only attacks where it has calculated that the odds favor them, and if you keep your units stacked and tidy, that is almost never (except the first winter (special rules)). 

Nothing really different from most hex/counter based games, just very broad in scope and very detalied in information. It could have been a very enjoyable game.

But.

The AI takes ages to calculate and complete it's turn. In the first few years this is bearable. But I arrived at turn 160 in late '44, and it takes the AI 15-30 minutes complete one turn, often with the only real action being bombing runs (of which there are no less than 100+, each with an autoresolve report, but that is only a fraction of the time). That truelly kills all immersion and gameplay, and really makes this a waiting game, a complete grind. Finishing off 20 partisan units every turn by moving a unit next to it does also not contribute to a vivid experience. (my PC was high end for the time the game came out: quad core i7 3,4, graphic card doesn't matter in this game, but was also high end)

I cannot imagine how you dare to sell a game for this amount of money, that is so severely testing your patience. All my 180+ hours played are from 3/4 of ONE playthrough by one side (admittedly I took much time learning and exploring the game, checking leaders, moving attachments around etc.). 

So, if you wonder if you should buy this, buy it only if you have a LOT (and I mean a LOT) of patience and are a die hard WW2 strategic fan, and then only if it is on sale. 

Rather sad, because if you are into realistic strategic WW2 games, this is a great game at it's core.

Now my first response would be:  "Where am I supposed to plug it in asshole?"  But if I humored this nosy lunatic I'd say unquestionably, "Anything by Graviteam Tactics, and Gary Grigsby's War in the (muthafunkin) East."

Here's why folks:  Graviteam Tactics puts out great tactical war stuff but this isn't their review page so forget that for now.  GG's WitE is the quintessential best, end all, beat all, WW2, Eastern Front, computerized operational level simulator ever on the planet.  That's right, I said it.  You can take that Hearts of Iron 4, pants-tightening chub and go sell it and that game to the tourists, skeezix, cuz this right here is what it's all about.  This is the cat's ass of Eastern Front, grognard wargamming.  Not sayin' HOI4 doesn't have it's place, but if you're the kinda dude (let's face it, absolutely zero women probably give a rat's hind end about the East Front and if there's one out there, well that's just one more female I've infuriated in my existence) that read "When Titans Clash" or "Enemy at the Gates" back in the day and it wasn't a college assignment , then this, my friend is for YOU. 

Yeah, it's a hefty $80 pricetag, but if someone sold you a $20, Christmas Sale Lincoln Navigator, I doubt that SOB would make it off the lot, and there'd probably be a dead hooker buried in the back that you'd have to explain to the cops as well.  WitE will indeed make it off the lot, purring like a V-8 hemi Charger, with zero dead hookers in the trunk.  

Why is it so great you ask?  Well, I'll lay it on you like Dolemite.  This monster encompasses the entire WW2 adventure from Germany's Barbarossa "What's the worst that could happen?" heyday to angry, vodka soaked Russkies rolling all up into Adolf's backyard like drunken soccer hooligans to camp out for the next 40 some-odd years at ye olde Reichstag. Unless of course, you're savvy enough to alter history with your mad, wargaming skills and turn Moscow into a Teutonic holiday retreat.  Good luck with all that, because it ain't gonna be easy, Herr Schlecte-Ahnung. 

As the Soviets, you're going to get your cossack handed to you in '41.  But like the real deal, your job is to minimize losses, sacrifice units, dodge Commrade Stalin's temper tantrums, make the Krauts pay for every inch of ground, and stop their encirclement shenanigans long enough until mud and winter roll into town.  Those ladies never disappoint.  You'll suffer too, make no mistake, but not as much as Winter-Fritz in '41 who failed to show up in cold weather gear enough to survive a Wisconsin Indian Summer.

I'm mainly talking about the Grand Campaign here, which is the real reason anybody walks the path to WitE.  Sure, you can play some limited scenarios if you want to.  Be sure and help yourself to some Shirley Temple's over there in the pink cooler while your at it, Sally.  Come join the Mensch when you feel up to it, but don't hurt yourself.   

This game is unparalleled in it's handling of minute details that you may or may not ever bother to look at.  But you will.  Eventually, we all look.  And half your game memories will consist of, "Yeah, the city was taken...but good Lord we lost a lotta guys doing it."  And, like the real war, you'll wind up writing off numbers of dead due to the sheer complexity of the titanic struggle.  

Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING is factored into this Goliath.  Weather, leaders (which you can change in and out with realistic limitations, or y'know, just have shot), supply, unit cohesion, the f'ing railroads and grade change once you get into real Russia, seaports (as Krauts I still can't take stinking Sevastopol due to their sea supply), air cover, air missions, updated gear and how long it takes to actually become available, scorched earth policies, pulling armor and transport out of units just to save on gas, fortifications, Western Front influences (this was a big one for me and is mirrored appropriately), partisans being a pain disrupting supply, SS units, Guards units, Police units (you can steamroll the town but unless military cops are there to hold it, it'll turn into Detroit sans Robocop).  Sickness and normal attrition play a role as well.  Hell, there's probably a graph chart depicting Pvt. Wiener Humpelstein's syphillis advancement and it's effect on his komrades but I just haven't found it yet.

There you go folks, there's my review.  Is it difficult to learn?  A bit, unless you apply yourself with the same gumption you gave towards getting ol' Heather McScrumpalot's bra off in the rear seat of your hand-me-down '78 Plymouth Duster back in high school.  And, not unlike then, you may hafta even take notes before diving in.

Good Wargaming, y'all, and wear a cup on this one.

28151622.review: Gary grigsby's war in the east is truly a collossal game. Encompassing the entirety of the eastern front, a prospective player can expect to be micromanaging everything down to brigade/regimental level. complete with a realistic and detailed combat system which models battles down to the individual smallarms possessed by infantrymen it is certaintly worth your money if you admire detail. while the game is excellent it does have several issues. the first of these is an issue inherent to the game genre itself namely the turn based nature of combat. while this does simplify combat to a manageable level it presents serious challenges in that combat is portrayed as a series of assaults against static units rather than being dynamic and fluid as it is in real life. the second major issue lies in casualties and supply. the game consistently underrepresents casualties sustained in engagements to the point that more often than nought both sides wind up with close to 100% strength. All in all this is an excellent game and I would strongly recommend it to anyone interested in the eastern front.  (ps: prospective buyers should be aware that work has begun on war in the east 2 and it is slated for release sometime in 2017)

24254184.review:
A good strategy game needs at least three things
- to be playable quickly, but also deep enough that you keep learning more for hours and hours
- have a decent UI which effectively organises information and commands
- have a competent AI.

War in the East has all these.  I bought it because Hearts of Iron 4 just didn't deliver in terms of realism or complexity, and so far I've been pleased with the purchase.  You can play the game fairly quickly after mastering basic concepts, but there is waaaay more to the game than just pushing units about.  Once you get into the longer scenarios you will start to find out that you really do need to know what's the difference between the equipment your regular and your SS motorized divisions have, you will need to consider how to airdrop fuel, where to cross that river, how you are going to break through and encircle, and, oh my God, winter is coming!

The game covers all the main scenarios of the invasion, as well as grand campaigns.  Combat, supply, leadership and infrastructure are all dealt with in clear but detailed and complex ways, and if you play through the scenarios in increasing complexity, you can slowly learn the mechanics of the game.  As I said, it allows you to get into the game, but after 15 hours I feel like I know know how much I don't know and which directions to learn.  This is a game you could sink hundreds of hours into.  The AI is competent and has caught me out, but with a human player the tension would be mental.  As for the price, I bought it on sale, as it does seem expensive, but the level of detail and historical faithfulness do make this worth the price.

And now to finish with the obligatory "would... again" list-
- Week 1. Push through northern USSR with the Finns coming in from the North.  Ahh the sun is shining, the panzers are rolling, and Soviet divisions are crumbling, life is good.
- Week 3. We get to Novgorod, and I now have to split my armies, the pesky Soviets seem to be holding the line a little better.
- Week 10.  The bitter seige of Leningrad continues... How many more men must be put through this mincer before the city falls?  Curse Stalin and his orders.  The Ju88s fly overhead on their way to bomb the port, but it makes no difference... I just want to go home.
- Week 12. Partisans have torn up the lines behind us, and they say we cannot get any fuel by air this week.  Still more good German men are being thrown at the Leningraders.  Why won't they surrender?  God help us, it's August, and we're running out of sunshine.
- Week 14.  We've taken the mainland suburbs of Leningrad at horrendous cost.  Still, throw enough howitzer shells at anyone and they soon melt into the past, no matter how fearsome their leader.  I've heard in the swamps to the south, our tanks have stalled against another Soviet line... the devil take this war...
- Week 16.  We've barely moved in 2 weeks, the encirclement south has come undone through massive Soviet reinforcement... The colonel says one more push, and Leningrad should fall...
.....
.......
.......
8/10 Would like to make a funny comment, but really, this war was beyond terrible.

Purchased WitE back in the day, which makes me old as 2010 isn't really Back in the Day. BitD is actually 1973 with the release of a paper hex map / cardboard counter game by the name of [i]Drang Nach Osten[/i]. The map was about 4' x 5', the counters totaled over 1,500 individual pieces. Add the expansion [i]Unentschieden![/i] (yes, they invented what would become DLC BitD), and the maps got bigger, with thousands more counters. It took hours just to set up, before ever actually playing. And the play... we met every Saturday night for about a year, and only got into 1943 before marriage, college, the military and various nervous disorders most often resemblng German and Russian language Tourette Syndrome broke up the group and brought the endevour to an end.

All of which is only backstory to my purchase of War in the East - technology has granted us the ability to actually play the beast that is The Great Patriotic War at the operational level without renting a hall and losing our minds. It's been done a number of times in recent decades, but Gary Grigsby has done it the best, by a wide margin. If you've read this far and have any idea what I'm talking about. AND are interested in the subject, then buy this game. I'd forgotten how good it is (getting it on Steam has reintroduced me and taken me away from other CCG and FPS for the past weeks), and how easy it is to immerse oneself in it. But back in the saddle it's the only thing I'll be doing for a while.

Like: It's the @#$%&*! East Front done right, for Zhukov's sake!

Dislike: It's 01:43 after a full work day, again, and I'm too tired to keep playing.

17857762.review:
For the old cardboard gamers out there, GG WiTE will be familiar.  Many may remember Avalon Hill's classic "Russian Campaign."   The manual is an impressive 377 A4 pages.  Despite this, the game can be played with remarkably little knowledge.  So while the learning curve is long, at the introductory level it is not steep.  After the initial interest of movement and combat you will soon find yourself persusing the manual to find out the finer detail and how to get an advantage on your opponent.   There are, thankfully, no boom/flash graphics.  A well laid out "board" with enough graphical detail to give information without being over the top.  Standard wargaming counters give it that classic boardgame feel.  Multiplayer is well catered for with the Matrix server providing the interaction between players.
So if you like classic wargaming, and part of the fun is reading through the manual, GG WiTE could be a good title to add to your collection.

17568118.review:
Gary Grigsby's War in the East est un "monster" wargame. C'est un jeu qui peut s'apparenter à Panzer général, pour ceux qui connaissent, mais avec une complexité et une profondeur tactique vraiment beaucoup plus importante.
Si vous ne connaissez pas Panzer général (ce que je peux comprendre car il date), c'est un jeu tactique tour par tour qui se déroule sur une grille d'hexagone comme fanal fantasy tactics, ogre tactics, disgaea, fire emblem pour citer quelques références provenant du monde consoleux (en espérant que ces citations vous parlent un peu plus). Pour ce qui est du qualificatif "monster" imaginez-vous à la tête d'une armée comptant environ 3 millions de soldats... Déjà que le nombre est impressionnant, mais dites-vous bien aussi que cela peut vous prendre pas mal de temps pour commander tout cela (jeu qui demande beaucoup de temps) ce qui peut être un frein important mais aussi un grand avantage, concernant la durée de vie du jeu...
Pour expliquer succintement les différences avec panzer général (que je qualifierai comme wargame de difficulté moyenne), dans Gary Grigsby's War in the East (abréviation W.i.t.e), vous gérez l'approvisionnement de vos troupes que ce soit en caburant et/ou en munitions, l'importance de votre appui aérien (quoique cette gestion est beaucoup plus prononcée dans Gary Grisgsby's War in the West, jeu sorti en 2014 uniquement disponible en boutique Matrix Games), mais vous avez aussi la possibilité d'appliquer des stratégies d'encerclement qui vous permettent, d'économiser d'importantes ressources en hommes et en munitions, et infliger en même temps d'importantes pertes en terme d'effectif humain, comme les prisonniers sont pris en compte dans le calcul des pertes. 
Pour ce qui est du prix du jeu, il est peut vous effrayer, mais rassurez-vous l'investissement en vaut la chandelle si vous êtes un tacticien hors-pair. Ce jeu est sorti il y a déjà 5 ans, mais les développeurs de 2 by 3 games continuent leur suivi sur ce jeu (chapeau bas messieurs).
Vous me direz aussi "mais ce jeu n'est pas traduit". Pour résoudre ce problème, le manuel a été traduit en francais (lien : http://www.wargamer.fr/war-in-the-east-manuel-en-version-francaise/), mais je vous conseille très fortement aussi le manel boot camp traduit en francais (lien : http://www.wargamer.fr/war-in-the-east-operational-boot-camp-guide-en-vf/).
J'espère que ce petit avis vous convaincra d'essayer ce magnifique wargame (comme on en fait plus désormais) et que la communauté française s'aggrandira.

N.B : Mon souhait serait qu'un jour on voit War in the West sur steam, et le réve ultime serait que les développeurs réunissent les deux fronts (je sais que dans War in the west il existe déjà une option qui influence les renforts provenant du front de l'est).

What does those 0% near "jars" mean?", "Why my Guards cant advance there!?", "Where are all my planes? Last week they were here, dozens of'em!" and etc. Read the manual and guides. Game provides you with all you need to know information, not overloaded by it, but to understand how to use it correctly you need to be ready to use manual.

If you are into World War 2 and ready to spend 1-3 hours on one turn - get it, cause it deserves every cent.

I would pay $300.00 for this game if I could just get all of the time I wasted trying to get other WWII Barbarossa games to do what this game does so effortlessly, i.e. Unity of Command is a fun game but because it is smaller scale even in the map editor UoC couldn't deliver my craving for a balls deep plunge into wide open Russia during Barbarossa 41.  This game rewards the knowledge you gain from each turn, and you start feeling like those Kraut armies of yours are all your own well disciplined children that are ready to wreak sytematic havoc and destruction on the Russians ahead.  You will feel proud of them as they attack fearlessly, with you knowing Hitler's meddling won't do them in this time.  You are going to show the world what a well organized modern army can do to it's enemies.  (at least this is how I felt after getting comfortable with my personal Russian whoop-ass mechanism).   

Forget Road to Minks, just start with the 224 turn 41-45 Barbarossa map and start going balls deep into Russia.
You will be thinking what a bunch of German generals thought in the first few weeks, Moscow by Labor Day perhaps.
Little by little your respect grows for the enormity of this map, the challenges of supply, an enemy driven by the whims of a brutal dictator, and the wonders of finding yourself balls deep in a vast and mysterious Soviet landscape.  Just start over each time you learn something awesome so by the 3rd or 4th Barbarossa you are feeling much more confident with your boys because you have the needed "trigger time" from 20 or so hours of gameplay. NEGATIVES:  Jeez, we are going to need a powerful microscope to find some dirt here, let me think....ok...there are no naked chicks in this game.  After 70+ hours of gameplay, nothing significant is coming to mind.  It appears pretty polished at this point.  I just want to get back to the game.

17178825.review:
If you are a wargamer and don't already have this game, you're doing it wrong.

I got into the hobby way back in the paper maps and cardboard counters era, and one of the things that always was a pain and made it extremely difficult to get to play these "monster games" as we called them was the sheer amount of free space and time needed to even get the game going, much less actually play it to the end. Not to mention the unending amount of bookkeeping involved. If you want to simulate manpower, replacement rates, supply etc., and you DO if you want any sort of realism in a wargame, you're going to have bookkeeping. Computers do all of that PLUS you don't have to have a spare garage to keep those giant maps and thousands of counters lying around for months while you play it. IF you can find somebody to play it WITH.

Now, back to this game. Old grognards like myself will remember cardboard titles like Drang Nach Osten/Unentschieden (Fire in the East/Scorched Earth) and Gary Grigsby's War in the East IS those games, only even better as you now have a computer capable of simulating everything down to the amount of ammo available for Mauser 98k rifles available to every single unit in the game. All behind the scenes so you don't have to bother if you don't want to. But you can, and if you ever want to know how many PzIVs you made this months, you can get that info too. Or not. You don't have to.

If you just want to push counters and conquer hexes, you can do that too, leaving almost everything else to the AI, which is very good at what it does. And that's the true beauty of this title, in my opinion. If you're just starting out and are a bit intimidated by the sheer size of this monster, and you have every reason to be, then don't worry. Just play. Select unit, move, attack, move some more, and let the computer handle the rest. Very intuitive and easy to get into.

If you want more, and eventually you will, then there's the extensive manual (almost 400 pages) that covers everything you might want to know. And so gradually you learn more and more about how your supplies work, how air power works, how to keep your units in supply, how to keep the enemy OUT of supply etc., all without having to learn it before moving a single counter. Too many games demand that you memorize the manual before you can even be moderately successful at playing the game, much less have any actual fun doing so. WitE is not one of those games, which is really impressive considering the amount of information and detail involved.

Historical? If you want something closer to history than this game, you'll probably have to invent a time machine and start learning how to speak German. The early lightning advances, watching your precious Panzers becoming shadows of their former selves as they race out of range of their own supplies as their supporting infantry struggles to keep up, watching everything come to a standstill as General Mud bogs down everything, grand encirclements, spending weeks reducing pockets of enemy troops cut off knowing that your infantry really needs to get the job done and get to the front before the Russians can start counterattacking your vulnerable flanks, you name it. WitE has it.

The price tag? Yes, it is expensive, but you'll be playing this game for years and years if wargaming is your thing, so you'll get your money back. If you're not sure if you'll ever like actual simulations of operational warfare as opposed to the beer and pretzels variety with pretty 3D icons, you should probably start off with something smaller, but if you're already interested in turn based wargames and the war on the Eastern Front, this is the game you absolutely have to have.

17122941.review:
Premessa, il conteggio delle ore di gioco di steam è bassissimo perché da anni gioco con la versione Matrix Games, il wargame è infatti del 2010, e con l'uscita sulla piattaforma di steam a tutti gli acquirenti è stata data una key steam.
Ciò premesso lo ritengo uno dei migliori wargame di sempre. 

Superato il cazzotto iniziale della curva di apprendimento molto ripida (non c'è un tutorial, circa 400 pagine di manuale, ma online si trovano molte guide e aiuti), il gioco regala un'esperienza fantastica, anche quando non si comprendono ancora tutte le meccaniche a fondo.

War in the East Ripercorre il fronte russo dall'inizio dell'inizio dell'Operazione Barbarossa fino alla capitolazione di Berlino (si può fare la campagna completa oppure singoli scenari).

E' estremamente simulativo, pertanto non sarà possibile stravolgere quanto realmente accaduto, ma in termini di gameplay una vittoria tedesca potrebbe consistere nell'arrivare al 1945 ancora col fronte in territorio sovietico e viceversa per i russi arrivare a Berlino un anno prima.

Se dobbiamo valutarlo sul piano dei wargame è molto simulativo per quanto riguarda i combattimenti di terra, semplificato per la fase aerea e dei rifornimenti e astratto per le operazioni di mare (quest'ultime minime e marginali per ovvie ragioni). A ciò si deve aggiungere un sistema molto dettagliato per quanto riguarda la gestione dei generali e comandati.

Preciso che War in the East ha 5 anni e per i wargame non deve essere considerato vecchio, anzi, solo con la recentissima patch si può considerare maturo. Infatti da anni escono patch e beta patch con cadenza bimestrale che hanno aggiunto molte modifiche al nucleo centrale del gioco. 
Bilanciare un gioco del genere, mantenendo un'assoluta fedeltà storica non è un compito facile.
Il gioco è costoso ma deve essere considerato una sorta di investimento, si acquista oltre al gioco un supporto costante e duraturo.

L'IA è buona, tuttavia si destreggia meglio coi sovietici in quanto l'esercito tedesco si basa su un movimento più ragionato.
Viceversa per il giocatore neofita è più facile utilizzare i tedeschi in quanto i rifornimenti e le dismissioni delle unità seguono quanto storicamente avvenuto, invece per i russi il giocatore deve creare le unità e gestire le varie fabbriche e manodopera e cercare di salvaguardarle il più possibile.

Possibilità di giocarlo con un avversario umano col sistema play by mail.

Inoltre esistono vari mod, in particolare consiglio la mappa creata da jison (trovate tutto sul forum ufficiale).

Per completezza va detto che è da poco uscito War in the West che ripercorre la guerra in Europa dal 43 (invasione della Sicilia) al 45. In linea teorica riprende la base di War in the East e la migliora, tuttavia è un gioco ancora immaturo, ha un andamento del gioco più a senso unico e a tutt’oggi lo trovo incompleto per varie ragioni che esulano da questa recensione...

Va detto infine che se giocato su un portatile full hd da 15 pollici le scritte risultano troppo piccole e si è costretti a diminuire la risoluzione. Per lo stesso motivo non è adatto per i monitor 4k. Insomma il gioco viaggia bene in full hd con uno schermo di almeno 17 pollici.

In definitiva, se ci si vuole avvicinare ai wargame veri questo è il gioco che consiglio.

17093818.review:
Gary Grigsby's War in the East simulates warfare on the Easter Front in the Second World War. It is a game you will either spend tens (ok, hundreds) of hours with... or you will just not get over the first hurdle of user interface & the manual. If you get over the interface and the hefty manual (highly recommended for new players, 100's of pages of important stuff), you need to gain understanding a rather delicate web of interdependencies, between morale, supply, air raids, HQ, generals, encirclements and evacuation. Than, AI will be piece of cake - but it will take tens and tens of hours to get to stage when you need to start playing Soviet Union on Hard to get some challenge.

However, the game begins when you start playing against humans. And you will find out that you have much to learn and that you do not know how to play. You will find that there are tricks, fine tricks and almost exploits. In any case, the game against expert player is quite different than even against very tough AI. Things are unfair, no matter which side you play... but also fun. You will understand that the system of interdependencies is much deeper and that micromanagement is much more important. I guarantee that during games against humans you will reach total despair, no matter which side you play. 

Hint: choose Soviets for your first game against human - they can fight even after you made quite some mistakes. Germans, Germans require a player class or two better than the opponent to succeed. But expertly played Axis is a very challenging opponent, even for an expert Soviet. At least until you stabilize in '42-'43.

To sum up, the game if you choose to get deep into it, will take hundreds of hours of play.  Worth it? Worth it if moving symbols over hexes is your thing. However, be careful if your family situation is strained and you should not get into a very complex game which will take hundreds of hours of your life. And if you do not like complex games, that is not the game for you. 


Pros:
[list]
[*] Complexity
[*] Details
[*] Most complete warfare simulation of the Eastern Front
[*] Really well thought out - though one can appreciate the finer design only after hundreds of hours played
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] Complexity - not a game for everyone
[*] Predicting the results of battles can be frustrating and require a lot of skill (one needs to take into account all the variables, that is morale, supply, type of units fighting, arms in the units etc - the numbers on the counters are only rough guidelines). That is doubly frustrating against expert human players as they can improve supply, morale etc. by skilled play leading to more difficult prediction of the results - as you do not know everything due to fog of war.
[*] Some balancing issues when facing expert humans
[*] Simulation of warfare only; no option to simulate production, interfere with the units armaments, etc
[*] Your social life will be in danger if you like complex wargames
[/list]

Check the AAR's here: [url=www.matrixgames.com/forums/tt.asp?forumid=910] AAR Forum [/url] 
[url=www.matrixgames.com/forums/tm.asp?m=3457737] My opponent AAR (two year old) - myself playing Germans	[/url]

17075343.review:
Kenchis AKA Cannonfodder

The Good

* IGOUGO and weekly turns make the game manageble and playable for wargamers that are time constrained (personally, I play War in the Pacific: Admirals Edition a lot, a monster with the one day is one turn structure...)
* Not for the faint of heart. It should actually have this printed on the box....
* Very. very detailed OOB and leader database
* Modable to a high degree
* Fun and challenging AI that can be tuned to your level of competence (by giving it bonuses) 
* "It is the 26th of June, 1941.. Your infantry smashed through the front line and Panzer Gruppe 2 and 3 just linked up west of Minsk. Infantry are already working on reducing the large pocket formed. Your tanks have fuel but the supply lines are long and the infantry is behind... What do you do, where do you go? YOU are in command...."

The Bad

* The air game is under developed and can be "gamed"
* IGOUGO and weekly turns can leave you wondering "what the hell just happened" in PBEM...
* Supply system is fairly basic and although it does constrain you it does not constrain you enough...
* The combat engine is very detailed and fun to dig in but it does complicate the game. Even the smallest tuning of devices can have large macro effects on the war
* Not for the faint of heart. It should actually have this printed on the box....

The future?

2by3 have used the base War in the East engine to develop War in the West (not available on steam). I've spent some hours in that game and while it introduces some features that are a bit rough around the edges (amphibous invasion, naval aspects, Eastern front box) it shows great promise in other areas (improvements to the supply system, a new air engine). 


Conclusion?

When you invest in War in the East, you invest in a good time [b]now[/b] but also in the future of a game engine that grognards aka war gaming enthusiasts will enjoy for years to come!

16985464.review:
You won't find a more detailed division level east front game on steam. Be advised this is a monster wargame.

1941-45 @ one week per turn. Old school...I do my turn and then you do yours. Rinse and repeat until victory or (player) morale failure.

Division and Bde level (bns & rgts assigned at Corps/Army level, CoC modelled very well

Units tracked by various types of supply (fuel, ammo...) fatigue, experience, morale...oh and by squad, mg and tank

The course of the war is one of amazing highs and lows regardless of the side you choose. Risks will have to be taken and disasters WILL occur. It will flow historically more or less if losses are near historical levels and skill levels aren't too far off but more or less casualties can lead to a very different army than seen historically. For example...woe to the Russian who threw away too many lives in low odds attacks and careless encirclements in 1942. Instead of standing up to the nazi invaders toe to toe...the retreat may very well continue throughout 43. I have won the game as the Germans in 1944 (admittedly against the ai)...panzers still pushing with all that late war goodness. Also been stopped cold in 42.

The war in the east from 1941-45 was by far the most brutal and total war ever fought by mankind. If you are seriously interested in learning about this conflict (and for anyone interested in military history, all other conflicts pale in comparison) this game is the only choice to make. Your only other serious options are TOAW, dosbox with this game's predecessor and vassal with a good boardgame. For the grogs and children of the grogs I can't possibly recommend this game enough. Don't give the price a second thought. 2 years after you delve into this game do the math...dollars vs hours. It will be cheap at that point. The thing is you're not done. Do the math again after four years and then six. Yeah, it's one of those games.

For the impatient, for those not interested at looking at the Soviet-German war (yeah and Hungry, Romania, Slovakia, Finland, Croatia and even a division from neutral Spain!) in it's totality, for those demanding something looking and sounding 'awesome' or immediate gratification move along. This isn't for you.

Do not be concerned at the age of this beast. Like a fine bottle of Scotch it has only improved with age. It is now very near a state of balance where any further changes carry both diminishing returns and the risks of unintended consequences. The game is ready for you.

16964772.review:
This isn't your average wargame. It's not World of Tanks. It's not Panzer General. 

This is massive. It's a simulation of the largest ground conflict in history. It models weather, ammunition, supply, logistics, partisans, air warfare, and of course combat. But because it's massive it can be daunting.

With all of that details come the challenge. At times it can be difficult to know if you're making the right choice. The interface can, at times, be overwhelming. All of the sudden a unit is highlighted in red. Why? It's not always evident immediately what is happening, or if it's significant. (Red highlight means it's out of supply range)\

I'd recomend starting with the 3 turn Scenario Road to Minsk. It's a quick fix, shows you the basics, but also is complex enough to offer a lot of replayability. With some of the longer scenarios it's easy to get lost and just see a wave of units. With the Minsk scenario you have a difficult objective. Not because the battles are hard, but because you must grab massive quantities of territory on top of conquering the enemy. For an added challenge, try the Soviet side. The game tacticvs change completely.

Which brings me to the full campaign. The monster that is Barbarossa. For myself it's too big. It's a massive theatre of war that quite frankly is daunting. Check out Grey Hunters Let's Play for a truly epic story. 

I'd love to see more scenarious I can tackle in an evening. I'd love to see tooltips to tell me exactly why that unit is highlighted yellow. Or why that attack failed. 

Through all of the detail and interface is an entertaining game. The first time you play just click and go. Then learn to encircle, learn to use multiple hexes (hint, select one hex to attack, then hover your mouse over the neighbors), then start longer games. 

War in the East is difficult, no doubt about it, but it's also an entertaining simulation.

39909323.review:
Together with War in the Pacific; Admiral's edition these games are the pinnacle of theatre wargaming. You do not manage politics, you do not manage trading, do not confuse this with the more popular "country management" games (such as those Paradox is known for). That is not to say country management games are bad, it is merely to say that this is not one of those games.

This game is about strategy and logistics. You manage the entire East Front military of either Germany or Russia. The game is hard to get a handle on as there is little you can't do within the scope of management of army and logistics. However the game`s UI is crystal clear and very helpful. Helpful icons in the top menu make is abundantly clear what they are intended for. Colour coded units show you wih a glance what units belong together in the OoB hierarchy. In short, while there are a lot of elements and mechanics to learn, the game never hides them (intentionally or otherwise).

My only "gripe" with the game, insofar as I have one, is the time granularity. Turns are on a week by week basis, so one of your turns equates to a full week of IRL simulated time. This along with the IGOUGO structure of the game turns your units into proverbial sitting ducks during an enemy turn. You will have to make sure that the position your units have at the end of YOUR turn accounts for the possible enemy actions of 1 week simulated time. Personally I would have prefered day by day turns like in War in the Pacific, but I can imagine the game would have become unwieldy especially for online play.

Some other notes I can not be bothered to write entire paragraphs on:
-The AI is solid, although as usual real players are superior
-Game runs smoothly, it won't stutter and lag on a decent machine...
-...however in later turns, especially on slow machines the AI will take a CONSIDERABLE amount of time to compute its entire turn. I myself have not had a problem with this, with the AI resolving their turn in no more than a minute or two, but I have heard from friends with slow machines that they have had to wait upwards of 10-15 minutes. So beware of this possibility.
-You do not get to make any decisions on production, again this is not a country management game in the style of HoI
-The focus lies HEAVILY on ground combat, aerial combat is present and important, but mechanically far less in depth. Naval combat is basically non existant (naval combat didn't play a huge role in the grande scope of the entire eastern front anyway)

In conclusion a fantastic game for warnuts out there, and I can not recommend this game enough to people who enjoy wargames.
